title: About
text: About this blog

title: Cuisines
text:
Cuisuines
EXPERIMENT OBJECTIVE:
This study seeks to analyze the nutritional and temporal characteristics influencing recipe patterns across global cuisines, specifically examining distributions across cuisine types, calorie content, cooking time durations, and user rating levels to determine correlations between measurable recipe attributes and user satisfaction metrics.

title: Cuisines
text:
5. Data Dictionary








Variable
Class
Description




Name
Factor
Name of the recipe


Country
Factor
Country or origin associated with the recipe/cuisine.


URL
Factor
Direct link to the recipe page


Author
Factor
Name of the contributor/author of the recipe.


Ingredients
Factor
List or string of all ingredients required for the recipe.


Date Published
Date
Date the recipe was first posted online.


Calories
double
Calories per serving


Fat
double
Total fat content in grams per serving


Carb
double
Carbohydrate content in grams per serving.


Protein
double
Protein content in grams per serving


Average Rating
double
Average star rating given by users (1–5)


Total Ratings
double
Total Ratings for the recipe


Reviews
double
Number of user reviews or ratings


Preperation Time
double
Preparation time in minutes


Cooking Time
double
Cooking time in minute


Total Time
double
Total estimated time for the recipe


Servings
double
Number of servings the recipe makes

text:
2. Which cuisines have the highest number of high-calorie dishes?

cuisines_modified2 %>%
  mutate(high_cal = calories > 600) %>%  
  group_by(country) %>%
  dplyr::summarise(high_cal_count = sum(high_cal, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%

  gf_col(reorder(country, high_cal_count) ~ high_cal_count, 
         fill = ~country) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Number of High-Calorie Dishes by Cuisine",
          y = "Cuisine Type", 
          x = "High-Calorie Recipe Count")

gf_point(country ~ calories, data = cuisines_modified2, 
         color = ~avg_rating, alpha = 0.6) %>%
  gf_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "black", 
            linetype = "dashed") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Relationship between Calories and Country's Cuisine by Average Rating",
          x = "Calories per Serving",
          y = "Country's cuisine",
          color = "avg_rating")

title: Cuisines
text: 9. Final Summary

title: Cuisines
section: Graph 1: Distribution of Recipes Across Global Cuisine
text: Graph 1: Distribution of Recipes Across Global Cuisine

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:

Vietnamese, Thai, Russian, and Indian cuisines dominate the dataset with 60+ recipes each.
Most cuisines cluster between 30-70 recipes, showing relatively balanced representation.
Belgian and Swiss cuisines have minimal representation (under 10 recipes).

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Russian cuisine has surprisingly high recipe count (similar to popular Asian cuisines), which is unexpected given its lower global visibility compared to Thai or Indian food.
Soul Food and Southern Recipes are categorized separately from general American cuisine, showing dataset’s attention to regional distinctions.

title: Cuisines
text: Graph 2: High-Calorie Dishes by Cuisine

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:

Cajun/Creole cuisine leads with ~18 high-calorie (>600 kcal) dishes.
Vietnamese, Thai, Southern Recipes, Spanish, and Chinese cuisines all have 12-15 high-calorie offerings.
Many cuisines (Swedish, South African, Israeli, Chilean at bottom) have zero high-calorie recipes in the dataset.

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Vietnamese cuisine appears at the top despite typically being perceived as lighter, healthier food, unexpected finding.
Traditional “heavy” cuisines like German and French show moderate high-calorie counts (8-10), less than expected.
The stark difference between cuisines (0 vs 18 recipes) suggests either dataset imbalance or genuine cultural differences in rich dish frequency.

title: Cuisines
section: Graph 3: Calories vs Cuisine by Rating
text: Graph 3: Calories vs Cuisine by Rating

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:
Most recipes across all cuisines fall between 200-800 calories per serving.
High-rated recipes (lighter blue, rating ~5) appear across the full calorie spectrum.
Cuban, Portuguese, and Colombian cuisines show the widest calorie ranges with outliers exceeding 2,000 calories.

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Several extreme outliers reach 2,000+ calories per serving, surprisingly high for single-serving recipes.
Lower-rated recipes (darker blue) don’t cluster around specific calorie ranges, suggesting calorie content doesn’t strongly predict ratings.

3.Vietnamese cuisine, despite high recipe count, shows relatively tight calorie clustering around lower ranges.

title: Cuisines
section: Graph 4: Cooking Time vs Cuisine by Rating
text: Graph 4: Cooking Time vs Cuisine by Rating

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:

Most recipes across all cuisines cluster under 500 minutes (8 hours) of total cooking time.
High-rated recipes (dark green, rating ~5) appear consistently across short and long cooking times.

3.Extreme outliers exist at 5,000-15,000+ minutes for cuisines like Canadian, Finnish, Russian, Korean, and Amish/Mennonite.

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Some recipes exceed 10,000 minutes (~7 days) of cooking time, likely fermentation, curing, or aging processes (Amish/Mennonite showing extreme duration).
No clear correlation between cooking time and rating,quick recipes can be just as highly rated as time-intensive ones.
German cuisine shows particularly wide time variation with multiple outlier recipes.

title: Cuisines
section: Graph 5: Average Rating Distribution by Country
text: Graph 5: Average Rating Distribution by Country

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:

Ratings show extreme positive skew, most recipes cluster between 4.0-5.0 stars.
Very few recipes rated below 3.0, with minimal representation under 4.0.
The distribution peaks sharply around 4.5 stars across all cuisines.

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Remarkably homogeneous rating patterns across all 50+ cuisines, no cuisine consistently performs better or worse.
The lack of low-rated recipes (under 3.0) suggests potential selection bias in the dataset or that only successful recipes make it into collections.
Rating distribution doesn’t reflect cuisine popularity or difficulty, contradicting expectations that complex cuisines might receive more varied feedback.

title: Cuisines
text: Graph 6: Calorie Distribution by Cuisine

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:

Median calorie content is remarkably consistent across most cuisines (around 300-500 calories).
Vietnamese, Turkish, Swiss, and Swedish cuisines show the tightest distributions with fewer outliers.
Southern Recipes, Spanish, and Soul Food show highest variability with numerous high-calorie outliers.

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Malaysian, Israeli, and Italian cuisines have exceptionally wide ranges with multiple extreme outliers reaching 1,500-2,000+ calories.
Amish and Mennonite cuisine shows surprisingly low and consistent calorie content despite stereotypes about rich, hearty foods.
Colombian cuisine has the widest interquartile range, suggesting highly diverse recipe types.

title: Cuisines
section: Graph 7: Correlation Analysis with Average Rating
text: Graph 7: Correlation Analysis with Average Rating

title: Cuisines
text:
Key Findings:

Number of reviews shows strongest positive correlation with ratings (r ≈ 0.10).
Total_ratings also positively correlates (r ≈ 0.08).
All cooking-related variables (cook_time, prep_time, total_time) show near-zero or slightly positive correlations.

title: Cuisines
text:
Unexpected Discoveries:

Servings shows negative correlation with rating (r ≈ -0.06), recipes serving more people tend to rate slightly lower, counterintuitive finding.
All correlations are surprisingly weak (all under 0.15), indicating recipe ratings are largely independent of measurable recipe characteristics.
The confidence intervals for all variables cross or approach zero, suggesting most relationships aren’t statistically significant.
Reviews/ratings variables correlate with average_rating more than actual recipe features (time, servings), suggesting rating behavior is more social than quality-based.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text: 4. Data Dictionary

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Quantitative Data

age (dbl): Respondent’s age in years
cvddef (dbl): Doctor-diagnosed cardiovascular disease status (0 = no, 1 = yes)
carstair (dbl): Carstairs deprivation score representing socioeconomic disadvantage
id (dbl): Respondent identification number
area (dbl): Geographic area code

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Qualitative Data
1.sex (fct): Respondent’s sex (factor with 2 levels: male/female) 2.sc (fct): Social class (factor with 3 levels) 3. smoke (fct): Smoking status (factor with 5 levels)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text: 5. Graphs

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: 1. Among non-smokers, does cardiovascular disease risk increase with age, and does this age-related increase differ between men and women?”
text:
1. Among non-smokers, does cardiovascular disease risk increase with age, and does this age-related increase differ between men and women?”

scottish_CVD_nonsmokers <- scottish_CVD_df_modified %>%
  filter(smoke == "nevr") %>%
  mutate(age_group = cut(age, 
                         breaks = c(18, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 79),
                         labels = c("18-29", "30-39", "40-49", "50-59", "60-69", "70-79"),
                         right = FALSE))

cvd_proportions_nonsmokers <- scottish_CVD_nonsmokers %>%
  group_by(age_group, sex) %>%
  summarise(proportion_cvd = mean(cvddef, na.rm = TRUE),
            .groups = "drop")

gf_col(proportion_cvd ~ age_group, 
       data = cvd_proportions_nonsmokers,
       fill = ~sex,
       position = "dodge") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Risk of Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) by Age and Sex (Non-Smokers Only)",
          x = "Age Group",
          y = "Proportion with CVD",
          fill = "Sex")

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: 2. Among smokers, does cardiovascular disease risk increase with age, and does this age-related increase differ between men and women?
text:
2. Among smokers, does cardiovascular disease risk increase with age, and does this age-related increase differ between men and women?

scottish_CVD_smokers <- scottish_CVD_df_modified %>%
  filter(smoke != "nevr") %>%
  mutate(age_group = cut(age, 
                         breaks = c(18, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 79),
                         labels = c("18-29", "30-39", "40-49", "50-59", "60-69", "70-79"),
                         right = FALSE))

cvd_proportions_smokers <- scottish_CVD_smokers %>%
  group_by(age_group, sex) %>%
  summarise(proportion_cvd = mean(cvddef, na.rm = TRUE),
            .groups = "drop")

gf_col(proportion_cvd ~ age_group, 
       data = cvd_proportions_smokers,
       fill = ~sex,
       position = "dodge") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Risk of Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) by Age and Sex (Smokers Only)",
          x = "Age Group",
          y = "Proportion with CVD",
          fill = "Sex")

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: 3. How do smoking status and age interact to affect cardiovascular disease risk, and are these patterns different for men and women?
text:
3. How do smoking status and age interact to affect cardiovascular disease risk, and are these patterns different for men and women?

scottish_CVD_mosaic <- scottish_CVD_df_modified %>%
  mutate(
    smoking_status = ifelse(smoke == "nevr", "Non-Smoker", "Smoker"),
    age_group = cut(age, 
                    breaks = c(18, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 79),
                    labels = c("18-29", "30-39", "40-49", "50-59", "60-69", "70-79"),
                    right = FALSE),
    cvd_status = factor(cvddef, 
                       levels = c(0, 1),
                       labels = c("No", "Yes"))
  )


mosaic_table <- xtabs(~ smoking_status + age_group + cvd_status + sex, 
                       data = scottish_CVD_mosaic)

vcd::mosaic(~ smoking_status + age_group + cvd_status | sex,
            data = mosaic_table,
            main = "Smoking Status, Age Group, and CVD by Sex",
            shade = TRUE,
            legend = TRUE,
            labeling_args = list(
              set_varnames = c(
                smoking_status = "Smoking Status",
                age_group = "Age Group",
                cvd_status = "CVD Status (0=No, 1=Yes)",
                sex = "Sex"
              )
            ))

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: 4. Are people who smoke more likely to have cardiovascular disease, and is this effect different by social class?
text:
4. Are people who smoke more likely to have cardiovascular disease, and is this effect different by social class?

scottish_CVD_mosaic2 <- scottish_CVD_df_modified %>%
  mutate(
    smoking_category = case_when(
      smoke == "nevr" ~ "Never",
      smoke == "ex" ~ "Former",
      smoke %in% c("mod", "hvy") ~ "Current",
      TRUE ~ as.character(smoke)
    ),
    smoking_category = factor(smoking_category, 
                             levels = c("Never", "Former", "Current")),
    cvd_status = factor(cvddef, 
                       levels = c(0, 1),
                       labels = c("No", "Yes"))
  )

mosaic_table2 <- xtabs(~ smoking_category + sc + cvd_status, 
                       data = scottish_CVD_mosaic2)

vcd::mosaic(~ smoking_category + sc + cvd_status,
            data = mosaic_table2,
            main = "Smoking Status, Social Class, and CVD",
            shade = TRUE,
            legend = TRUE,
            labeling_args = list(
              set_varnames = c(
                smoking_category = "Smoking Status",
                sc = "Social Class",
                cvd_status = "CVD Status"
              )
            ))

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: 5. Does Risk of CVD Increase with Age and Deprivation?
text:
5. Does Risk of CVD Increase with Age and Deprivation?

gf_point(age ~ carstair, 
         data = scottish_CVD_df_modified,
         color = ~factor(cvddef, labels = c("No CVD", "CVD")),
         alpha = 0.4,
         size = 2) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Does Risk of CVD Increase with Age and Deprivation?",
          x = "Carstairs Deprivation Score (Higher = More Deprived)",
          y = "Age (years)",
          color = "CVD Status")

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: 6. Do smokers live in more deprived areas than non-smokers, and does this relationship differ between men and women?
text:
6. Do smokers live in more deprived areas than non-smokers, and does this relationship differ between men and women?

scottish_CVD_smoking <- scottish_CVD_df_modified %>%
  filter(!is.na(smoke), !is.na(carstair), !is.na(sex)) %>%
  mutate(
    smoking_category = case_when(
      smoke == "nevr" ~ "Never",
      smoke == "ex" ~ "Former",
      smoke == "mod" ~ "Moderate",
      smoke == "hvy" ~ "Heavy",
      TRUE ~ as.character(smoke)
    ),
    smoking_category = factor(smoking_category, 
                             levels = c("Never", "Former", "Moderate", "Heavy"))
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(smoking_category))

ggplot(scottish_CVD_smoking, aes(x = smoking_category, y = carstair)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~ sex) +
  labs(title = "Deprivation Level by Smoking Status and Sex",
       x = "Smoking Status",
       y = "Carstairs Deprivation Score") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text: 6. Summary

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: Graph 1: CVD Risk by Age and Sex (Non-Smokers Only)
text: Graph 1: CVD Risk by Age and Sex (Non-Smokers Only)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Key Findings:

CVD risk increases dramatically with age even among non-smokers, rising from ~8% in the 18-29 age group to over 50% in the 70-79 age group.
There’s a clear age-related progression, with the steepest increase occurring after age 50.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Unexpected Discovery:
In the oldest age group (70-79), females actually have higher CVD prevalence than males (~55% vs ~42%), which contradicts the typical pattern seen in younger age groups where males have higher risk. This reversal suggests that biological aging may affect women’s cardiovascular health more severely in later life, possibly related to post-menopausal changes.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: Graph 2: CVD Risk by Age and Sex (Smokers Only)
text: Graph 2: CVD Risk by Age and Sex (Smokers Only)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Key Findings:

Smokers show substantially higher CVD rates than non-smokers across all age groups, with prevalence reaching ~65% for males aged 70-79.
The age-CVD gradient is steeper among smokers, indicating that smoking accelerates age-related cardiovascular damage.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Unexpected Discovery:
The sex difference pattern is inconsistent across age groups, in the 40-49 age group, males have notably higher CVD (~24% vs ~20%), but in the 50-59 group, females catch up significantly (~42% vs ~35%). This suggests that smoking may have more pronounced effects on women’s cardiovascular health in middle age, possibly due to interactions with hormonal changes.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: Graph 3: Smoking Status, Age Group, and CVD by Sex (Mosaic Plot)
text: Graph 3: Smoking Status, Age Group, and CVD by Sex (Mosaic Plot)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Key Findings:

The mosaic plot confirms strong associations between smoking, age, and CVD, with significant Pearson residuals (p < 2.22e-16).
Blue-shaded tiles (positive residuals) indicate combinations that occur more frequently than expected, particularly CVD cases among older smokers.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Unexpected Discovery:
Among young male non-smokers (18-29 age group), there’s a strong blue shading for CVD=No, indicating this group has even fewer CVD cases than would be expected by chance. Conversely, there’s notable red shading (negative residuals) for older female smokers without CVD, suggesting that smoking has particularly strong effects on older women’s cardiovascular health, fewer escape CVD than statistical models would predict.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: Graph 4: Smoking Status, Social Class, and CVD (Mosaic Plot)
text: Graph 4: Smoking Status, Social Class, and CVD (Mosaic Plot)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Key Findings:

Social class shows strong associations with both smoking behavior and CVD risk (p < 2.22e-16).
Current smokers in lower social classes (4-5) show strong positive residuals (blue shading) for CVD=Yes, indicating clustering of multiple risk factors.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Unexpected Discovery:
Social class 1-2 (highest class) never-smokers show strong blue shading for CVD=No, they have even lower CVD rates than expected. However, the most striking finding is that former smokers in social class 4-5 show strong blue residuals for CVD=Yes, suggesting that even after quitting smoking, people in lower social classes continue to have elevated CVD risk. This indicates that smoking cessation alone may not eliminate the cardiovascular burden in socioeconomically disadvantaged populations, likely due to other persistent risk factors (diet, stress, healthcare access, environmental exposures).

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text: Graph 5: Age vs Deprivation Score (Scatterplot)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Key Findings:

CVD cases (blue/teal points) are distributed across all deprivation levels and ages, but show higher concentration in older age groups.
The scatterplot reveals the full distribution of individuals rather than aggregated proportions.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Unexpected Discovery:
There is no strong visible linear relationship between age and deprivation score, the points are fairly evenly distributed across the Carstairs scale at all ages. This is unexpected because it suggests that area deprivation and individual age are independent risk factors rather than correlated variables. People of all ages live in both deprived and affluent areas. Additionally, CVD cases appear across the entire deprivation spectrum, though visual inspection suggests slightly higher density in more deprived areas (positive Carstairs scores). This reinforces that while deprivation increases CVD risk at the population level, substantial numbers of people in affluent areas still develop CVD due to other risk factors.

title: Cardiovascular Disease
section: Graph 3: Deprivation Level by Smoking Status and Sex (Box Plot)
text: Graph 3: Deprivation Level by Smoking Status and Sex (Box Plot)

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Key Findings:

Both moderate and heavy smokers show higher median Carstairs scores (indicating more deprivation) compared to never-smokers and former smokers​
The pattern is consistent across both sexes, confirming the social gradient in smoking behavior

title: Cardiovascular Disease
text:
Unexpected Discovery:
Former smokers show very similar deprivation distributions to never-smokers, rather than intermediate levels between never-smokers and current smokers. This suggests that smoking cessation may be more common among those in less deprived areas, or that people who successfully quit smoking may have different socioeconomic profiles than those who continue smoking. Additionally, the wide distribution and numerous outliers indicate substantial individual variation, many people in highly deprived areas don’t smoke, and some in affluent areas do.
